abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Project for
            Nicaragua were as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: flexibility by the Bank in the face of
            changing government policy may be needed to secure continued
            development impact. Ultimately, the sustainability of an
            education reform depends on information transparency,
            communications, and buy-in from stakeholders. In developing
            the project, the World Bank provided strong technical
            support to design the school autonomy model. Donor
            coordination and a sector-wide approach (SWAP) can continue,
            and even be strengthened in the face of adversity and
            significant policy change. The use of country systems
            contributed to the long-term sustainability of World Bank
            support to the education sector in Nicaragua.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Project for
            Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the inadequate assessment of risks
            at the beginning of the original Project design was a major
            factor in the discontinuity of certain activities and in the
            need for restructuring. Support of all stakeholders matters,
            and it is important to maintain coalitions to support
            reforms. Project preparation should clearly identify
            possible fragile points in the coalitions to support
            reforms. Even though identifying the exact reasons why the
            government decided to abandon the school autonomy program
            goes beyond this document, there is evidence of
            dissatisfaction with the model from parents and teachers at
            its early stages, in most cases due to challenges in the
            relationship with principals. The original and the
            restructured project designs had two very different concepts
            of decentralization embedded in them, with different
            accountability mechanisms, in the original design,
            decentralization was at the school level, while during the
            restructured design, and decentralization was at the
            departmental level. Nonetheless, under both approaches,
            information is the key to accountability. But information
            coming from test can be affected by curriculum changes.
            Therefore, in order to achieve comparability through time
            tests could focus on student competences. Another option to
            assess evolution of the education system is to participate
            in international tests to provide benchmarks through time.
            These considerations have been taken into account in the
            design of the new project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Education Project
            (PASEN) for Nicaragua aim to: (a) improve institutional
            management capacity and information systems to improve
            service delivery; (b) improve systems of governance and
            accountability, including measures to strengthen community
            participation in the education sector; (c) improve the
            quality of education through monitoring and disseminating
            student learning outcomes; and (d) harmonize donor
            assistance in the education sector. The extension is
            necessary to complete the purchase, printing and
            distribution of goods financed by the project. This
            includes: (i) the purchase of two computer server units to
            improve the efficiency of the Ministry of Education (MINED)
            network system; books for distribution to school libraries
            for primary; other learning materials for distribution to
            secondary non-formal education; school supplies for
            distribution to primary schools in the non-formal education
            system and 16 laptops for the Primary and Teacher Training
            Directorates of MINED; and (ii) the printing of learning
            materials (guides, brochures, curriculum materials, and
            learning aids) for distribution to primary school teachers
            and school administrators. MINED has prepared a plan of
            action for completion of these activities prior to the
            revised closing date. This will be the third extension of
            the project, bringing the total cumulative extension to
            three years.
